issues.description: The problem statement and solution refer to a class named Meal (and show its UML/usage), but the template repository does not provide a Meal implementation (Meal.java is empty) and instead contains an Order.java class with the same structure. This mismatch (Meal vs Order) is likely to confuse students about which class to use/implement and contradicts the problem text that says Meal is fully implemented.
issues.suggested_fix: Make the template consistent with the problem statement: either provide a properly implemented Meal.java in the template (and remove or rename Order.java), or update the problem statement to refer to Order instead of Meal. Preferably remove/rename the extraneous Order class and include the Meal implementation so students see the expected class name and can implement SealSaloon against Meal as described. Also update the commented examples in Main to reference Meal to avoid further confusion.

issues.description: The problem statement consistently refers to the domain entity as 'Meal' (including the class diagram and textual descriptions), but the template repository provides an 'Order' class with the same fields and API shape (name, ingredients). The solution repository implements the expected 'Meal' class. This name mismatch (Meal vs Order) across problem description, template, and solution creates a mapping barrier: students will look for a Meal class to implement or use, but the template contains an 'Order' class instead (and an empty Meal.java), which is likely to cause confusion about which class to edit or instantiate.
issues.suggested_fix: Align the identifier names so the same conceptual entity uses the same class name across artifacts. Recommended fixes: (a) Rename the template 'Order' class/file to 'Meal' (Order.java -> Meal.java) and update any references (e.g., Main comments), or (b) implement the empty template Meal.java with the same content as the template Order class and remove the Order class. Ensure the problem statement, template, and solution consistently use 'Meal' to avoid student confusion.
